questions.text: A 36-year-old patient was posted for surgery. He was given glycopyrrolate before anesthesia. What is the rationale for giving glycopyrrolate before anesthesia?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

To decrease secretions Glycopyrrolate has antagonistic action on M3 receptors present in glands like salivary and tracheobronchial glands and decreases their secretions so it is used as pre-anesthetic medication. Glycopyrrolate is used as a pre-anesthetic medication to decrease salivary, tracheobronchial, pharyngeal, and gastric secretions (a quaternary compound that does not cross BBB)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. For muscle relaxation: Muscle relaxants like pancuronium, vecuronium, atracurium & rocuronium are used. Option B. To decrease anxiety: Benzodiazepines like midazolam is used. Option C. To induce anesthesia: Propofol, etomidate & ketamine are used for induction.

Extraedge:

Glycopyrrolate does not cross the blood brain barriers (BBB),,,,, due its polar (charged) structure,, & therefore does not exert CNS effects. This is unlike other commons antimuscarinics such as atropine which are non-polar (uncharged) and can cross the BBB. Uses: In anaesthesia as preoperative medication → reduce salivary, tracheobronchial, and pharyngeal secretions decreasing the acidity of gastric . secretion. Conjunction with Neostigmine prevent muscarinic side effects Neurological conditions such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis to reduce excessive saliva

questions.text: A patient came in with bradycardia and was given atropine. Which of the following is not seen with atropine given to this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Contraction of sphincter pupillae Atropine is parasympatholytic with antagonist action on M1, M2, and M3 receptors. So, it causes mydriasis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Atropine affects Option A. Reduces gastric secretion (M1 ⓧ) Option B. Increases av conduction (M2 ⓧ) Option C. Decreases in trachea bronchial secretions (M3 ⓧ) By relaxing sphincter pupillae (Not contraction), it causes mydriasis

Extraedge:

Actions of Atropine On Respiratory: bronchial dilatation, decrease secretion. Gastrointestinal (GIT): Antispasmodic due to reduction of GIT motility. Block salivary glands secretion → drying of oral mucosa (xerostomia). On GUT: smooth muscles of ureter and bladder wall are relaxed and urination is slowed. Exocrine glands secretions: All decrease (except Milk)→ dry mouth, dry eyes, dry skin (inhibit sweating), bronchial secretion decrease & become viscid.

Table:

Cycloplegics and mydriatics mechanisms : Atropine, cyclopentolate, and tropicamide are antimuscarinics that are available for ophthalmic use and cause cycloplegia to a variable extent. This cycloplegia/paralysis of accommodation occurs due to their parasympathetic action, which decreases the tone of the ciliary body. In elderly people who have a low ciliary tone, phenylephrine is preferred as a mydriatic. This is because other anticholinergics can precipitate or aggravate glaucoma by relaxation of the ciliary muscles and altering the forces acting on trabecular meshwork for aqueous outflow. Atropine has both mydriatic and cycloplegic action, which is required for refraction testing.

questions.text: A 76-year-old male patient was taking Haloperidol for schizophrenia for the last 2 months. Now he comes to the clinic with symptoms like bradykinesia, muscle rigidity, and gait abnormality. Which of the following drugs will help in the treatment of these patients’ new symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Benzhexol This is a case of drug-induced Parkinson's disease, due to D2 blockade by haloperidol

Highyeild:

Trihexyphenidyl(benzhexol), biperiden, and benztropine are central anticholinergics used for drug-induced Parkinson's disease, acute dystonia, and akathisia Scopolamine, glycopyrrolate, and clidinium are anticholinergics but not approved for drug-induced Parkinson's disease

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Scopolamine (hallucination and sedation) is used in narco analysis as a truth serum Option C. Glycopyrrolate is a potent and rapidly acting antimuscarinic lacking central effects . It is almost exclusively used for pre-anesthetic medication and during anesthesia. Option D. Clidinium is an antisecretory-antispasmodic that has been used in combination with benzodiazepines for nervous dyspepsia, gastritis, irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), colic, peptic ulcer, etc.

Extraedge:

Extrapyramidal Symptoms Reaction Onset Features Acute dystonia Hours to 5 days Spasm of tongue, neck, face & back Parkinsonism 5-30 days Tremor, shuffling gait, drooling, stooped posture, instability Akathesia 5-60 days Compulsive, repetitive motions; agitation Tarditive dyskinesia Months to years Lip-smacking, worm-like tongue movement, 'fly-catching'

Table:

Benzhexol Equivocal preliminary results from small studies exist for: Other Dyskinesias Huntington's Chorea Spasmodic Torticollis Dystonia Abuse: It has euphoriant and aphrodisiac properties therefore it is abused. Smoked, insufflated, swallowed, or dissolved under the tongue

questions.text: A 22-year male patient had an injury from a plant to his eyes. After a few days, he developed a fungal corneal ulcer. He was given antifungal drugs & oral analgesic for pain. The ophthalmologist wanted to add atropine as adjunctive therapy. The reason is:

options.label: C
options.text: To prevent synechiae and relieve pain

questions.correct_answer: C. To prevent synechiae and relieve pain
questions.explanation:
Solution:

To prevent synechiae and relieve pain

Highyeild:

Specific initial treatment of fungal infections of the cornea: Antifungal drugs with atropine. Adjunctive treatment: Atropine 1 percent or homatropine 2 percent to dilate the pupil (Not to decrease pupil size – Option B) & to prevent synechiae and relieve pain Oral analgesics: To reduce pain Anti-glaucoma drugs: If IOP is increased

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: Although atropine can decrease lacrimation, it is not used here for that purpose, so it can’t be the answer here. Option B: Atropine causes an increase (mydriasis) in pupil size and not a decrease (miosis). Option D: Atropine reduces the ciliary muscle spasm and causes relaxation of ciliary muscles.

questions.text: Atropine was given at a high dose to a child to treat accidental OP poisoning. After some time, the body temperature was high. The reason could be:

options.label: C
options.text: Both a and b are true

options.label: D
options.text: Both a and b are false

questions.correct_answer: C. Both a and b are true
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both a and b are true

Highyeild:

Atropine causes a rise in body temperature at higher doses. This is because of Inhibition of sweating Stimulation of temperature regulating center in the hypothalamus. Children are more susceptible to atropine fever than adults.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option C & D Are Incorrect Statement

Extraedge:

Atropine in OP poisoning Atropine is competitive antagonist of Ach at muscarinic receptor Has no effect on muscle weakness and paralysis No effect on AChE reactivation Role Control of pulmonary secretion and bronchorrhoea Control seizures and CNS manifestation of poisoning

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy child was brought by the parents to an ophthalmologist. When asked, they said that the boy cannot copy what the teacher is writing on the board and was making mistakes while writing. They wanted to rule out refractive error and came to the clinic. Atropine was used to dilate the pupil before refraction testing and why is that the preferred mydriatic in this child?

options.label: A
options.text: Longer duration of action of atropine

options.label: B
options.text: Increased tone of the ciliary muscle in children

questions.correct_answer: B. Increased tone of the ciliary muscle in children
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increased tone of the ciliary muscle in children

Highyeild:

Atropine It is the strongest cycloplegic Cycloplegia is necessary for controlling accommodation and obtaining accurate refraction in young children Refractive testing in children should be preferably done under cycloplegia Atropine is the gold standard for complete cycloplegia Atropine needs at least 3 hours to reach peak effect and must be used for 3 days to produce complete cycloplegia It takes 8-14 days for its effect to wash out from the pupil and ciliary body.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: Although there is a longer duration of action of atropine, still it is used here to decrease the tone of ciliary muscles since there is a higher tone in children. Option C: There are more side effects due to the use of atropine. Option D: Atropine can be easily administered to the child but option B is a better answer since it is asked.

Extraedge:

Actions of atropine: Mydriasis: by blocking the contraction of sphincter pupillae muscle Decreased secretions from salivary glands and lacrimal glands - by blocking M1 & M3 receptors. Tachycardia due to its vagolytic activity at the M2 receptor. Decreased sweating by inhibiting sympathetic cholinergic supply to sweat glands which makes the skin hot and dry (Atropine fever).

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented in the OPD with complaints of increased frequency in micturition. Also, sudden urge to micturate which is difficult. He has advised antibiotics along with another drug. What can be the most likely drug which is advised for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Flavoxate In UTI, patients may have overactive bladders and to prevent frequent and sudden urge to urinate, anticholinergic drugs can be used. In the given options, it is flavoxate which is anticholinergic used in overactive bladder

Highyeild:

Anticholinergics used in the overactive bladder are Oxybutynin Tolterodine Trospium chloride Darifenacin Solifenacin Fesoterodine, flavoxate Fesoterodine is a prodrug that is rapidly hydrolyzed to the active metabolite of tolterodine by esterases

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A . Bethanechol is a muscarinic receptor agonist which is used to treat urinary retention and inadequate emptying of the bladder when an organic obstruction is absent, as in postoperative urinary retention, diabetic autonomic neuropathy & certain cases of chronic hypotonic, myogenic, or neurogenic bladder Option C. Finasteride is a 5 alpha-reductase inhibitor that is used in the treatment of Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH) Option D. Flutamide is an androgen receptor antagonist which is used in the treatment of prostate cancer

Extraedge:

Drugs for overactive bladder and detrusor instability with the mechanism of action : M3 receptor antagonists: Darifenacin, solifenacin Quarternary compounds: Trospium Direct smooth muscle relaxants : Flavoxate, Oxybutynin Other drugs: Tolterodine

questions.text: A patient with Alzheimer's disease was also having an overactive bladder. Which of the following will you prescribe to this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Trospium

Highyeild:

Trospium: Used for urinary frequency, urgency and incontinence in detrusor hyperreflexia. Tolterodine: Claimed to have greater selectivity on bladder M3 receptors than salivary M3 receptors. Dose reduction in Hepatic impairment Propiverine: Causes drowsiness with CNS depressents. Trospium is a Quaternary amine that crosses BBB minimally , So there is less chance of interfering with Alzheimer's disease Trospium can be used with anticholinesterases like rivastigmine in Alzheimer's disease patients having an overactive bladder

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, B & C. Tolterodine, oxybutynin, and flavoxate are anticholinergics used as urinary antispasmodics (vesicoselective). These drugs may cross BBB & may have CNS effects. Hence, they are not used in Alzheimer’s disease.

Extraedge:

Treatment of the overactive bladder Behavioural therapy Drug therapy Muscarinic receptor antagonists Intravesical medication Transdermal medication (oxybutynin) Surgical management Intravesical botox Sacral neuromodulation Bladder augmentation

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic smoker wanted to quit smoking after counseling. He decided to start on drugs with family support and thorough counseling. The drug used acts as a partial agonist at the α4β2 nicotinic receptor and the drug used is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Varenicline

Highyeild:

Drugs for smoking cessation : Nicotine replacement therapy Long-acting preparations: transdermal patches Shorter acting preparations: gums, lozenges, nasal spray, inhaler mouth spray Drugs : Varenicline (most effective therapy): it is a nicotinic Alpha4Beta2 partial agonist. Bupropion: it is NDRI ( noradrenaline dopamine reuptake inhibitors ). It is used for smoking cessation along with its anti-depressant properties.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Buspirone acts as a full agonist on the 5HT1A receptor & used in the treatment of anxiety disorders. Option C. Pregabalin binds to the alpha2-delta subunit of presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels in the CNS and has antagonistic action. Option D. Acamprosate acts as a weak NMDA receptor antagonist & is used as an anti-craving drug.

Extraedge:

Varenicline is a partial agonist at α4β2 nicotinic receptor This type of nicotinic receptor subtype is involved in nicotine addiction Used as an anti-smoking agent FDA has given a warning on CVS risk and increased suicidal risk

questions.text: A patient came in with renal colic and was given a Spasmolytic drug, and the drug acts through a non-cholinergic mechanism. The drug is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Drotaverine

Highyeild:

Non-anticholinergic smooth muscle relaxant In smooth acts by inhibiting phosphodiesterase-4 (pde-4) Increased camp/cGMP attends smooth muscle relaxation Use in intestinal, biliary, and renal colics, irritable bowel syndrome, uterine spasms, etc . Without anticholinergic side effects

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Oxybutynin, tolterodine, and darifenacin act on M3 receptors in the bladder and have antagonistic action.

Extraedge:

Drugs for overactive bladder and detrusor instability with the mechanism of action : M3 receptor antagonists: Darifenacin, solifenacin Quarternary compounds: Trospium Direct smooth muscle relaxants : Flavoxate, Oxybutynin Other drugs: Tolterodine
